questions.text: Which of the following stains can be used for laryngeal mass seen during laryngoscopic examination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Supra vital The images shows irregular growth over true cords probably malignancy, which can be confirmed by Supravital staining Supravital staining is carried out during Micro laryngoscopic examination when the patient is intubated This provides accurate information concerning the presence of atypical, carcinoma in situ and non-keratinising carcinoma

Highyeild:

Supravital staining in laryngeal cancer: The patient is intubated with a cuffed endotracheal tube After cleaning the vocal cords of excess mucus, 2% toluidine blue or 2% azure blue is painted generously on the mucosa of the larynx and Subglottic area After 30 seconds the excess dye is irrigated off with saline Areas of atypical, arcing a in situ and superficial non-keratinising carcinoma will stain blue-black Normal pavement epithelium remains unstained Biopsy from the stained area is most likely to reveal dysplastic or neoplasticism epithelium

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Congo red Option: B. Silver nitrate Option: C. H&E These stains are not used for diagnosis of laryngeal cancer during laryngoscopic examination

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department with epistaxis and a nasal mass. What is the investigation of choice to evaluate his condition? Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography - (CECT) Paranasal Sinuses - (PNS) Magnetic Resonance Imaging - (MRI)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CECT PNS and nose According to the details given in the question, 18 year, male, epistaxis, nasal mass , the diagnosis should be juvenile nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma The investigation of choice for this is CECT PNS and nose

Highyeild:

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is now the investigation of choice. It has replaced all conventional radiographs. CT shows the extent of the tumour, bony destruction or displacements. Anterior bowing of the maxillary sinus's posterior wall , often called an antral sign or Holman Miller sign, is pathognomic of angiofibroma. Other Investigations : CT scan - Investigation of choice -To see the origin , extent of growth and bony erosions. MRI - To see the soft tissue extension and to differentiate intradural and extradural tumour Digital subtraction angiography - To see the extent , vascularity and feeding vessel Blood grouping and matching - To arrange blood intraoperatively , if required

Table:

#MANTRA Signs in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma Antral sign/Holman – Miller sign: Anterior bowing of posterior maxillary wall. Hondusa sign: Increase distance between maxilla and mandible cheek swelling +. Frog face deformity: Tumor is in orbit and Ethmoid.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and a sensation of objects moving around her. She is diagnosed with left vestibular neuritis. Her head impulse test is positive. What is the correct finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Right saccade with right side movement

options.label: B
options.text: Right saccade with left side movement

options.label: C
options.text: Left saccade with right side movement

options.label: D
options.text: Left saccade with left side movement

questions.correct_answer: C. Left saccade with right side movement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left saccade with right side movement The question gives us the diagnosis of vestibular neuritis In this, there is nystagmus towards the healthy ear and corrective saccades in the direction opposite to the nystagmus Hence, option C is the correct answer

Highyeild:

Vestibular Neuritis: Sudden onset of sustained severe dizziness, nausea, sickness and postural imbalance is the characteristic presentation of vestibular neuritis Aetiology: A selective inflammation of the vestibular nerve is the most favourable aetiology. Inflammation of a nerve may cause demyelination and associated loss of function, which can be irreversible Symptoms: Sudden onset of persistent vertigo Autonomic symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor. Severe symptoms would normally last for a few days before gradually starting to spontaneously resolve. There should be no associated cochlear symptoms (hearing loss and tinnitus), neurological symptoms or signs of brainstem lesion The superior nerve is more commonly affected with vestibular neuritis, which may be explained by its course through a longer and more narrow bony canal making it susceptible to swelling causing entrapment Characteristic clinical examination findings with acute vestibular neuritis: Horizontal–torsional spontaneous nystagmus, beating away from the side of the lesion, more vigorous without optic fixation Head thrust test positive on the same side as the lesion Gait test and Unterberger test show deviation to the side of the lesion Romberg test shows marked increase of sway Treatment: Symptomatic treatment with antiemetic medication during the acute stage is often required, and antihistamines, anticholinergic agents and antidopaminergic agents are the most commonly used drugs. Fluid replacement may be necessary in particularly severe cases Vestibular rehabilitation exercises

questions.text: Match the following with the nerve supply of external ear:

options.label: A
options.text: A - Auriculotemporal nerve; B - Greater auricular nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve

options.label: B
options.text: A - Greater auricular nerve; B - Auriculotemporal nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve

options.label: C
options.text: A-Greater auricular nerve; B - Facial and Vagus nerve; C - Auriculotemporal nerve

options.label: D
options.text: A - Facial and Vagus nerve; B - Greater auricular nerve; C - Auriculotemporal nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Greater auricular nerve; B - Auriculotemporal nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A - Greater auricular nerve; B - Auriculotemporal nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve Vagus nerve Parts marked as A - Greater auricular nerve; B - Auriculotemporal nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve Hence, the correct option is B

Highyeild:

Nerve supply of pinnacle: Greater auricular nerve (C2,3) supplies most of the medial surface of pinna and only posterior part of the lateral surface Lesser occipital (C2) supplies the upper part of the medial surface. Auriculotemporal (V3) supplies tragus, crus of helix and the adjacent part of the helix. Auricular branch of the vagus (CN X), also called Arnold’s nerve, supplies the concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface. Facial nerve, which is distributed with fibres of the auricular branch of the vagus, supplies the concha and retroauricular groove. Nerve supply of pinna. (A) Lateral surface of pinna. (B) Medial or cranial surface of the pinna.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Refer explanation of correct option

questions.text: A female singer presents with hoarseness of voice and difficulty singing in a high pitch. On laryngoscopy, it was noted that one vocal cord is bowed, positioned lower than the other, and the associated muscle is shortened. Which muscle is likely affected in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cricothyroid The question says patient has difficulty singing in high pitch, the muscle responsible for high pitched voice is cricothyroid The paralysis of this muscle causes these symptoms

Highyeild:

MUSCLES OF LARYNX Intrinsic muscles. They may act on vocal cords or laryngeal inleta. Acting on vocal cords : Abductors: Posterior cricoarytenoid Adductors: - Lateral cricoarytenoid Interarytenoid (transverse arytenoid) Thyroarytenoid (external part) Tensors: - Cricothyroid Vocalis (internal part of Thyroarytenoid) Acting on laryngeal inlet: Openers of laryngeal inlet: - Thyroepiglottic (part of thyroarytenoid) Closers of laryngeal inlet: - Interarytenoid (oblique part). Aryepiglottic (posterior oblique part of interarytenoids Extrinsic muscles. They connect the larynx to the neighbouring structures and are divided into elevators or depressors of larynx. A) Elevators: - Primary elevators act directly as they are attached to the thyroid cartilage and include stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, palatopharyngeus and thyrohyoid. Secondary elevators act indirectly as they are attached to the hyoid bone and include mylohyoid (main), digastric, stylohyoid and geniohyoid. B) Depressors. They include sternohyoid, sternothyroid and omohyoid.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Posterior Cricoarytenoid: It is the only abductor of larynx Option: B. Lateral Cricoarytenoid: It is one of the adductors of larynx Option: C. Interarytenoid: It is one of the adductors of larynx

Table:

#MANTRA Intrinsic muscles of the larynx Those acting on the vocal cord Abductors Posterior cricoarytenoid Adductors Lateral cricoarytenoid Interarytenoid Thyroarytenoid Tansors External- Cricothyroid Internal- Vocalis Those acting on the laryngeal inlet Opening the inlet Thyroepiglottis (part of thyroarytenoid) Closing the inlet Interarytenoid (oblique part) Aryepiglottic (posterior oblique part of interarytenoid) Extrinsic muscles of the larynx: Elevators Primary Stylopharyngeus Salpingopharyngeus Palatopharyngeus Thyrohyoid Secondary Mylohyoid Stylohyoid Digastric Geniohyoid Depressors Sternohyoid Sternothyroid Omohyoid

questions.text: What is the marked structure of the cochlear implant shown below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ground electrode The part marked as question mark is ground electrode

Highyeild:

Cochlear Implants A cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids. Components and Functioning of a Cochlear Implant: A cochlear implant has an external and internal component. External component. It consists of an external speech processor and a transmitter. The speech processor may be body worn or behind the ear type. Internal component. It comprises the receiver/stimulator package with an electrode array and is surgically implanted. Parts of cochlear implant Function principle: The microphone in the speech processor- It picks up the sound and analyses and codes sounds into electrical pulses → The electrical impulses are sent from the processor to the transmitting coil → Transmitting coil to surgically implanted receiver/stimulator via radiofrequency → The receiver/stimulator decodes the signal and transmits it to the electrode array → The electrode array in the scala tympani of the cochlea stimulates the spiral ganglion cells → Thereby stimulating the auditory nerve → sends these electrical pulses to the brain → These are interpreted as sound Components of Cochlear Implants External Component (Remain outside the body) Internal Component (Fitted inside the body) ● Microphone ● Speech-processor ● Transmitter ● Receiver/Stimulator (Implanted under the skin) ● Electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea)

questions.text: A patient presented with nasal congestion and upon examination, nasal polyps were observed. A coronal CT scan of the patient was taken and is as shown below. Which of the following sinus drainage pathways is likely to be affected? CT - Computed Tomography
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maxillary Left maxillary sinus shows haziness , it has mucosal thickening and probably there is collection Frontal and sphenoid sinuses are not visualised in this Ethmoidal sinuses are clear

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Ethmoid-Ethmoidal sinuses are clear in the given CT Option: B. Frontal-It is not visualised in the given image Option: D. Sphenoid-It is not visualised in the given image

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with mild, progressive, bilateral hearing loss. A PTA showed the following findings. What is the most likely clinical finding in this patient? PTA - Pure Tone Audiogram
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schwartze Sign The PTA image shows dip at 2000Hz in BC curve, this is seen in Otosclerosis Schwartz sign is seen in otosclerosis

Highyeild:

Signs in Otosclerosis: Schwartz signs—Flamingo pink in the tympanic membrane is seen in 10% of cases. It indicates active Focus with increased vascularity. Stapes footplate—Shows a rice grain/biscuit-type appearance Pure tone audiometry shows loss of air conduction, more for lower frequencies. Bone conduction is normal. In some cases, there is a Carhart’s notch in bone conduction, disappears completely after successful stapedectomy Blue mantles are seen histopathologically

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Hennebert sign- A positive fistula sign in the absence of a fistula seen in syphilis Option: B. Hitzelberger sign-Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall (sup- plied by CN VII) is seen in acoustic neuroma Option: D. Bryce's sign-Seen in laryngocele. When the swell- ing is pressed, a gurgling sound is produced.

questions.text: The patient complains of repeated episodes of crusting in the nose with occasional bleeding. She had undergone surgery for nasal obstruction four months back. On examination, the following finding is seen. Which surgery has the highest likelihood to result in this complication?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Submucosal resection The image shows a septal perforation and history mentions previous septal surgery. Hence, the surgery done should be submucosal resection.

Highyeild:

Septal perforation: Aetiology: Traumatic Perforations. Pathological Perforations: They can be caused by: Septal abscess.- Nasal myiasis Rhinolith or neglected foreign body causing pressure necrosis. - Chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis and leprosy cause perforation in the cartilaginous part while syphilis involves the bony part. Wegener’s granuloma Drugs and Chemicals Idiopathic Clinical features: Small anterior perforations: whistling sound during inspiration or expiration. Larger perforations: develop crusts which obstruct the nose or cause severe epistaxis when removed. Treatment: Find out the cause before treatment of perforation. Inactive small perforations can be surgically closed by plastic flaps. Larger perforations: difficult to close, so treatment is aimed to keep the nose crust-free by alkaline nasal douches and application of a bland ointment. Note: Septal perforation is the most common complication of submucosal resection, as most of the cartilage is removed in this surgery

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Septal perforation is not a complication of FESS /Denker’s / Inferior meatotomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding an esophageal foreign body?

options.label: C
options.text: Most common site of impaction is at level of cricopharyngeus

options.label: D
options.text: One of the constrictions of the esophagus is at the level of the right bronchus

questions.correct_answer: C. Most common site of impaction is at level of cricopharyngeus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Most common site of impaction is at level of cricopharyngeus The given image shows an oesophageal foreign body, the site of impact of which is crico pharynx. Hence, option C is right.

Highyeild:

SITE OF LODGEMENT OF FOREIGN BODY: The commonest site is at or just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter. Foreign bodies which pass the sphincter can be held up at the next narrowing at broncho aortic constriction or at the cardiac end. Sharp or pointed objects lodge anywhere in the oesophagus. Once they pass the oesophagus, they are likely to pass per rectum but sometimes it might get obstructed at pylorus, duodenum, terminal ileum, ileocaecal junction, caecum, sigmoid colon or even at the rectum.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - All other statements are false.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with hearing loss in the left ear and episodic pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, there was a mass in the middle ear behind the tympanic membrane. A CT performed is as shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glomus jugulare According to the question, the patient has hearing loss and pulsation tinnitus with mass behind the tympanic membrane The CT image shows Phlep’ s sign which differentiates glomus jugulare and tympanicum The given findings suggest the diagnosis of glomus jugulare

Highyeild:

Clinical features : When the tumour is intratympanic. Hearing loss is conductive and slowly progressive. Tinnitus is pulsatile and of swishing character, synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure. Otoscopy shows a red reflex through intact tympanic membrane. “Rising sun” appearance is seen when a tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear. “Pulsation sign” (Brown sign) is positive, i.e. when ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, tumour pulsates vigorously and then blanches; reverse happens with the release of pressure. When tumour presents as a polyp. In addition to hearing loss and tinnitus, there is a history of profuse bleeding from the ear. Dizziness or vertigo and facial paralysis may appear. Examination reveals a red, vascular polyp filling the meatus. It bleeds readily and profusely on manipulation or at biopsy. Cranial nerve palsies. This is a late feature appearing several years after aural symptoms. IXth to XIIth cranial nerves may be paralyzed. Audible bruit Investigations : High resolution Computed tomography (CT) scan of temporal bone. It helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumour by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter - known as Phlep’s sign MRI

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Refer explanation of correct option

questions.text: In which procedure is the incision showed in the image used?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Open rhinoplasty The given image shows an inverted V shaped incision This is used in Open rhinoplasty

Highyeild:

Incisions used in rhinoplasty:

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss. On examination, a small perforation is noted on his left tympanic membrane. What will be the left-sided Rinne's test finding in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Negative Rinne’s test is negative in cases of perforation of tympanic membrane As it causes conductive hearing loss

Highyeild:

Rinne’s test: In this test air conduction of the ear is compared with its bone conduction. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he still hears, AC is more than BC. Alternatively, the patient is asked to compare the loudness of sound heard through air and bone conduction. Rinne test is called positive when AC is longer or louder than BC. It is seen in normal persons or those having sensorineural deafness. A negative Rinne (BC > AC) is seen in conductive deafness. A negative Rinne indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 15–20 dB. A prediction of air-bone gap can be made if tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz are used. A Rinne test equal or negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 20–30 dB. A Rinne test negative for 256 and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 30–45 dB. A Rinne negative for all the three tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 45–60 dB. False Negative Rinne. It is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Positive-It is positive in normal hearing and sensorineural hearing loss Option: B. False positive-In cases of tympanic membrane perforation, Rinne’s is negative Option: D. Intermediate-This is not a finding of Rinne’s test
